clusters.title: Woman found dead with two young children home, man arrested
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman Found Dead, Man Arrested in Cobram
bullet_summary: Homicide Squad detectives are investigating after a woman, 32, was found dead in Cobram, with her two young children at home but physically unharmed
Police found the 32-year-old woman's body about 5am this morning

items.title: Woman found dead with two young children home, man arrested
items.standfirst: Homicide Squad detectives are investigating after a woman, 32, was found dead in Cobram, with her two young children at home but physically unharmed.
items.content: Homicide Squad detectives are investigating after a woman, 32, was found dead in Cobram, with her two young children at home but physically unharmed.

items.title: Man arrested after woman found dead in Cobram home
items.standfirst: Police found the 32-year-old woman's body about 5am this morning.
items.content: Police found the 32-year-old woman's body about 5am this morning.

items.title: Man arrested after woman found dead at home in northern Victoria
items.standfirst: Two young children were in the house at the time.
items.content: A man has been arrested after a woman was found dead at a home near the NSW-Victoria border this morning.Police were called to a home in Cobram about 5 am following reports a 32-year-old woman had been found deceased.A 45-year-old man, who is known to the woman, has been arrested.READ MORE: Flood warnings issued as a week of rain hits east coast Two young children who were at the home were not physically injured during the incident.Detectives from the Victoria Police Homicide Squad are headed to the scene and will interview the man.Cobram is located on the Murray River, on the border between NSW and Victoria, and is about 260km north of Melbourne. National Sexual Assault, Domestic Family Violence Counselling Service 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732).

clusters.ai_summary:
• A 32-year-old woman was found dead in Cobram, Victoria, with two children present.
• Police have arrested a man in connection with the woman's death.
• Homicide Squad detectives are investigating the death of the woman.

clusters.title: Man dead at childcare centre after forcing way in
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Dies After Confrontation at Childcare Centre
bullet_summary: Reported by The Age, ABC News Australia, 9News

items.title: Man dead at childcare centre after forcing way in
items.standfirst: The 28-year-old had broken into the Sunshine Coast childcare centre, and was declared dead after a confrontation with police.
items.content: The 28-year-old had broken into the Sunshine Coast childcare centre, and was declared dead after a confrontation with police.

items.title: Man dies after police confrontation at Sunshine Coast childcare centre
items.standfirst: The police Ethical Standards Command is investigating the death of a man at a childcare centre on Queensland's Sunshine Coast.
items.content: The police Ethical Standards Command is investigating the death of a man at a childcare centre on Queensland's Sunshine Coast.

items.title: Man dies at Sunshine Coast childcare centre in confrontation with police
items.standfirst: H e was treated at the scene of a suspected burglary by emergency services but died there.
items.content: A n investigation has been launched into the death of a man at a childcare centre in a confrontation with police on the Sunshine Coast.Emergency services were called to a disturbance at the centre about 6pm yesterday in Peregian Springs, south of Noosa.Police found a 28-year-old man who had broken into the building and had serious injuries from self-harming.READ MORE: iiNet cyberattack exposes details of 280,000 customersOfficers attempted to negotiate with the man before taking him into custody. He became unresponsive soon after.Police at the scene rendered first aid before other emergency services arrived, but he was declared dead a short time later.No other person present at the time of the incident was physically harmed.The death is under investigation by the Ethical Standards Command on behalf of the state coroner and is under independent oversight by the Crime and Corruption Commission.Anyone with information should call 131 444, or make an online report. Readers seeking support can contact Lifeline on 13 11 14 or beyond blue on 1300 22 4636.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.ai_summary:
• A man died after a confrontation with police at a Sunshine Coast childcare centre.
• The man had broken into the childcare centre before the confrontation.
• The police Ethical Standards Command is investigating the man's death.

items.title: Australia news live: CSL to sack thousands of staff and get out of vaccine business; former RBA governor blames Labor for his unpopularity
items.standfirst: Follow today’s news liveGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastFinance minister says government disappointed, but ‘not surprised’ after Israel revokes visasFinance minister Katy Gallagher said the government is disappointed after Israel revoked the visas of Australian representatives to the Palestinian Authority overnight. Gallagher said the Labor government was not surprised by the move, which came after Anthony Albanese said Australia would recognise a Palestinian state and after the country refused a visa yesterday for a far-right member of Israeli parliament.At a time when we need more diplomacy and more dialogue between countries, it is a disappointing decision. We’re not surprised necessarily by it. We saw similar steps taken against other countries …But certainly our view is this is unjustified and we need more talk, more diplomacy, more channels in for discussion than we’ve needed before. Continue reading...

items.title: Infant found inside stormwater drain in Perth was two weeks old
items.standfirst: Western Australia Premier Roger Cook described the incident as a "horrifying scenario".
items.content: T he body of an infant found in a stormwater drain in Perth's north was just two weeks old, it has been revealed.Emergency services responded to reports a child had been discovered inside the drain in Alexander Heights about 1pm (3pm AEDT) yesterday.The discovery triggered a city-wide alert to maternity hospitals.READ MORE: 'Do the deal': Trump hosts historic White House war summitWestern Australia Premier Roger Cook described the incident as a "horrifying scenario"."The mother of that child must be incredibly distressed," Cook said."Those workers that discovered the child's body were confronted with the most distressing of circumstances."My heart goes out to everyone involved in this horrible, horrible series of events."This goes to the heart of everyone's sense of humanity, a small child whose life has passed under tragic circumstances," he added.Multiple resources attended the scene on La Salle Road, which was closed to the public.READ MORE: 'Ketamine Queen' enters plea over Matthew Perry's deathTradespeople working on the storm drain sounded the alarm after making the shocking discovery. A number of ambulance crews were called but stood down soon after when they realised there was nothing they could do to save the infant.This evening, police issued an emergency alert to all Perth maternity hospitals with concerns for the welfare of the mother.Detectives this afternoon spent a long time talking to all the neighbours on the street, looking for CCTV and asking if they'd noticed anything suspicious in the past 48 hours.They were expected to remain on the scene for some time. The gender of the child has not been confirmed. An investigation into the discovery of the child's body is ongoing.Anyone with information is urged to contact police immediately on 131 444.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: One Nation senator resigns just three months after election
clusters.neutral_headline: One Nation Senator Resigns Due to Health Issues

items.title: One Nation senator resigns just three months after election
items.standfirst: One of the party’s two new senators, Warwick Stacey, has quit because of unspecified health issues, creating a vacancy in NSW.
items.content: One of the party’s two new senators, Warwick Stacey, has quit because of unspecified health issues, creating a vacancy in NSW.

items.title: Health issues force senator to resign just months after election
items.standfirst: O ne Nation senator Warwick Stacey hadn't even had the chance to give his first speech in parliament.
items.content: J ust months after claiming a seat in parliament in an election upset, One Nation senator Warwick Stacey has resigned from the upper house due to health issues.The senator announced he will vacate his seat after just two sitting weeks and before even being able to give his maiden speech, because "he could not in good conscience bring anything less than a 100% dedicated effort to his role"."Unfortunately, I will be unable to fully dedicate myself to the role as I deal with my personal health issues," Stacey said.READ MORE: Infant found inside stormwater drain in Perth was two weeks old "I don't think a person elected to parliament should be anything less than completely dedicated to a role entrusted to them by voters, so I'm resigning to make way for someone who can do that on behalf of the people of NSW."He didn't provide any detail about the nature of his health issues. One Nation leader Pauline Hanson said she fully supported Stacey's decision and wished him all the best."Warwick Stacey is a man of principle and a great Australian," she said."It is with profound regret that we farewell him from the Senate so soon after he was elected."I was delighted when it was announced Senator Stacey had won a seat representing NSW. "I knew he would bring a wealth of knowledge, experience and expertise to our team along with the strong conservative values that made Australia great. "READ MORE: At least 280,000 Aussies exposed in major cyberattack Stacey's election in May's federal election was a major upset, coming from behind on preferences to edge out Labor for the final seat in NSW after then-Nationals deputy leader Perin Davey lost her spot in the Senate.Along with a similar victory in Western Australia, it gave One Nation two extra seats in the upper house this term.READ MORE: Push to overhaul tax concessions 'hurting ordinary Aussies' "I thank Senator Hanson and One Nation for giving me the opportunity to serve and represent my state in Canberra – it was a memorable campaign that saw our party's vote rise across the country," Stacey said."I thank the people of NSW for trusting me with this role. I thank the staff members who joined my office to work with a brand-new senator."I also wish all the best to my successor and the One Nation team."Unlike in the House of Representatives, parties are allowed to choose their own replacement for a senator who has resigned.Hanson said the party would announce Stacey's successor in the coming weeks. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.ai_summary:
• One Nation senator Warwick Stacey resigned due to unspecified health issues.
• Stacey had only been in office for three months after the election.
• His resignation creates a vacancy in the New South Wales Senate.

clusters.title: Trump-Zelensky White House meeting LIVE updates: US president says no peace until he, Putin and Zelensky meet
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump and Zelensky Meet at White House

items.title: Trump-Zelensky White House meeting LIVE updates: US president says no peace until he, Putin and Zelensky meet
items.standfirst: Trump hosted Volodymyr Zelensky at an Oval Office press conference that was far more cordial than the last time he and the Ukrainian leader met.
items.content: Trump hosted Volodymyr Zelensky at an Oval Office press conference that was far more cordial than the last time he and the Ukrainian leader met.

items.title: Back in the Oval Office, Zelenskyy wears a suit and Trump doesn't shout
items.standfirst: It was only a few months ago that U.S. President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy last met in the Oval Office, but today's face-to-face between the two leaders looked markedly different.
items.content: It was only a few months ago that US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy last met in the Oval Office, but today's face-to-face between the two leaders looked markedly different.For much of their February exchange, during which Trump and Vice President JD Vance blasted Zelenskyy as “disrespectful” and warned about future American support for his country, Zelenskyy crossed his arms and looked warily at the US leaders.The presidents often spoke over each other, also gesturing disagreement. A conservative reporter, Brian Glenn, even asked Zelenskyy why he wasn't wearing a suit.READ MORE: 'Do the deal': Trump hosts historic White House war summitToday's meeting was rounded out with more smiles and pleasantries between Trump and Zelenskyy, as well as agreement on some points regarding Russia's ongoing war against Ukraine.Both men largely sat with their hands clasped in their laps, affably fielding questions from reporters.Glenn, when called upon by the Republican U.S. president to speak, complimented Zelenskyy, saying, “You look fabulous in that suit.”READ MORE: Call for 'death tax' to help Australia raise $70 billionTrump chimed in right after: “I said the same thing!”"I apologise to you. You look wonderful," Glenn said, and as he tried to segue to an actual question.Zelenskyy, a comedian before he became president, quipped to Glenn, "You are in the same suit. I changed, you did not."Afterwards, Trump claimed the meeting with Zelenskyy was a "very good meeting" .- With CNN, AP DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Europeans hail Ukraine talks with Trump but divisions remain over ceasefire
items.standfirst: The US president and his Ukrainian counterpart, Volodymyr Zelensky, held a much more conciliatory encounter in the Oval Office than their infamous February meeting.
items.content: The US president and his Ukrainian counterpart, Volodymyr Zelensky, held a much more conciliatory encounter in the Oval Office than their infamous February meeting.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Trump and Zelensky held a meeting at the White House.
• The meeting was described as more cordial than their previous encounter.
• Europeans are hailing the talks, but divisions remain over a ceasefire.

clusters.title: Dandenong stabbing a 'targeted' attack, police believe
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Dies After Stabbing in Dandenong

items.title: Dandenong stabbing a 'targeted' attack, police believe
items.standfirst: Police on patrol spotted the man after he collapsed outside a service station just before 5am.
items.content: A man who died outside a Melbourneservice station this morning was stabbed in what police at this stage believe to be a targeted attack.Detective Inspector Dead Thomas said police had been on patrol along the Princes Highway in Dandenong when they saw the man collapse outside the BP on Potter Street at about 4.50 am. The officers provided first aid until paramedics arrived. READ MORE: 'Do the deal': Trump hosts historic White House war summitHowever, the 39-year-old died at the scene.Thomas said it appeared the man had been injured inside a nearby unit before fleeing to the street.He said the attack may have taken place at about 4.35am. No weapon has been found but police have located a phone outside, which will be examined in connection with the case.Nobody has been arrested. Thomas said at this stage, there was no suggestion the attacker lived at the address. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: 'Ketamine Queen' to plead guilty to selling drugs that killed Matthew Perry
clusters.neutral_headline: Ketamine Queen" to Plead Guilty in Perry Death

items.title: 'Ketamine Queen' to plead guilty to selling drugs that killed Matthew Perry
items.standfirst: Jasveen Sangha is the fifth and final defendant to be charged with the actor's death.
items.content: Jasveen Sangha is the fifth and final defendant to be charged with the actor's death.

items.title: 'Ketamine Queen' accused of selling fatal dose to Matthew Perry agrees to plead guilty
items.standfirst: S he faces up to 45 years for her role in the death of the Friends star who died from using the drug.
items.content: A woman known as the "Ketamine Queen," charged with selling Matthew Perry the drug that killed him, has agreed to plead guilty.Jasveen Sangha becomes the fifth and final defendant charged in the overdose death of the Friends star to strike a plea agreement with federal prosecutors, avoiding a trial that had been planned for September.She agreed to plead guilty on Monday (Tuesday AEST) to five federal criminal charges, including providing the ketamine that led to Perry's death, federal prosecutors said in a statement.READ MORE: Zelenskyy, Trump express hope for trilateral talks with Putin to bring end to Russia-Ukraine war Prosecutors had cast Sangha, a 42-year-old citizen of the US and the UK, as a prolific drug dealer who was known to her customers as the "Ketamine Queen," using the term often in press releases and court documents and even including it in the official name of the case.She agreed to plead guilty to one count of maintaining a drug-involved premises, three counts of distribution of ketamine, and one count of distribution of ketamine resulting in death or serious bodily injury.She admitted in the agreement to selling four vials of ketamine to another man, Cody McLaury, hours before he died from an overdose in 2019. McLaury had no relationship to Perry.Prosecutors will drop three other counts related to the distribution of ketamine, and one count of distribution of methamphetamine that was unrelated to the Perry case.Sangha will officially change her plea to guilty at an upcoming hearing, where sentencing will be scheduled, prosecutors said. She could get up to 45 years in prison. An email sent to Sangha's lawyers seeking comment was not immediately answered.READ MORE: Local resident's 'bizarre, illegal' trick to change speed limitShe and Dr Salvador Plasencia, who signed his own plea deal on June 16, had been the primary targets of the investigation. Three other defendants — Dr Mark Chavez, Kenneth Iwamasa and Erik Fleming — agreed to plead guilty last year in exchange for their cooperation, which included statements implicating Sangha and Plasencia.Perry was found dead in his Los Angeles home by Iwamasa, his assistant, on October 28, 2023. The medical examiner ruled that ketamine, typically used as a surgical anesthetic, was the primary cause of death.The actor had been using the drug through his regular doctor as a legal, but off-label, treatment for depression, which has become increasingly common.Perry, 54, sought more ketamine than his doctor would give him. He began getting it from Plasencia about a month before his death, then started getting still more from Sangha about two weeks before his death, prosecutors said.Perry and Iwamasa found Sangha through Perry's friend Fleming. In their plea agreements, both men described the subsequent deals in detail.Fleming messaged Iwamasa saying Sangha's ketamine was "unmarked but it's amazing," according to court documents. Fleming texted Iwamasa that she only deals "with high end and celebs. If it were not great stuff she'd lose her business."With the two men acting as middlemen, Perry bought large amounts of ketamine from Sangha, including 25 vials for $US6000 in cash four days before his death. That purchase included the doses that killed Perry, prosecutors said.On the day of Perry's death, Sangha told Fleming they should delete all the messages they had sent each other, according to her indictment.Her home in North Hollywood, California, was raided last March by Drug Enforcement Administration agents who found large amounts of methamphetamines and ketamine, according to an affidavit from an agent. She was indicted that June, arrested that August and has been held in jail since.None of the defendants has yet been sentenced.Perry struggled with addiction for years, dating back to his time on Friends, when he became one of the biggest stars of his generation as Chandler Bing.He starred alongside Jennifer Aniston, Courteney Cox, Lisa Kudrow, Matt LeBlanc and David Schwimmer for 10 seasons from 1994 to 2004 on NBC's megahit series.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Jasveen Sangha will plead guilty to selling drugs that killed Matthew Perry.
• She is the fifth defendant charged in connection with the actor's death.
• Sangha faces up to 45 years in prison for her role in the death.
